ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

JURONG EAST SPORTS COMPLEX
(Construction of)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    1. To ask the Minister for National Development when the construction of the

Column: 198

Jurong East Sports Complex at Jurong Town Hall Road/Boon Lay Way will begin.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, on 17th March 1988, I informed the Member for Yuhua that the Sports Complex at Jurong East is

Column: 199

expected to be completed by the end of 1990.

    Following a recent review of the use of land in the vicinity of Jurong Lake, my Ministry has decided to reserve the prime site at the junction of Jurong Town Hall Road and Boon Lay Way for comprehensive development. The proposed Jurong East Sports Complex will, therefore, be located to an alternative site. The complex is now expected to be ready by the end of 1991.

VACANT LAND AT JURONG EAST STREET 24
(Development plans)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    2. To ask the Minister for Education what development plans his Ministry has for the piece of vacant land in front of Blocks 263 and 264, Jurong East Street 24, the former site of Yuhua Primary School.

     Dr Vasoo: Question No. 2, Sir.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Tang Guan Seng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The vacant land in front of Blocks 263 and 264, Jurong East Street 24, is part of a secondary school site. By this, I mean Jurong East Site 4.

    There are no plans at the moment to develop this site. The site will be retained by the Ministry of Education until such time when another secondary school is required in the area.

USE OF DISPOSABLE CROCKERY AT HAWKER CENTRES


    3. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for the Environment (a) which hawker centres are currently required to use disposable utensils; (b) whether it is compulsory for hawkers at such centres to use disposable utensils; and (c) which other hawker centres will be required to use disposable utensils over the next twelve months.

Column: 200



     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, currently 15 hawker centres are using disposable crockery as part of a pilot project of my Ministry to improve the standards of hygiene and cleanliness in hawker centres. The pilot project was completed last year.

    In view of the many complaints received from both hawkers and their customers, the Government has re-considered the proposal to require hawkers to use disposable crockery.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has no intention of interfering with market demands and consumer preferences so long as standards of public health are maintained. My Ministry will, therefore, not compel hawkers to use disposable crockery. However, Sir, in hawker centres where the turnover is high, we will encourage hawkers to have disposable crockery available so that customers who prefer to use them may do so.

Column: 200

TOUTING
(Measures to discourage)


    4. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) if he will give a progress report on measures taken by the Government to discourage touts from harassing tourists in the Orchard Road shopping belt; and (b) when amending legislation will be introduced to deal with the touting problem adequately.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year my Minister informed this House that the Government took a serious view of the problem of touts and had adopted a multi-pronged approach to tackle it.

    The Police have intensified their enforcement action against touts by deploying officers on anti-tout rounds and mounting regular blitzes. From July to December 1988, 157 touts as well as persons selling counterfeit goods were arrested and charged in court. 133 pleaded guilty and were fined between $600 and $1,000 under the Trade Marks Act and from $120 to $160 under the Penal Code. Sir, in the first nine

Column: 201

days of this year, 49 touts were arrested and charged in court.

    We also took enforcement action against shopsengaging touts to sell counterfeit goods. The Police have worked very closely with the management of shopping complexes and interested organizations to keep shops selling counterfeit goods in check. The close cooperation has resulted in many successful raids under the Trade Marks Act.

    The Police have also recently invoked against touts Section 105 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap. 68) which smpowers a District Court to order any person not to repeat or continue a public nuisance, a breach of which would enable the Police to prosecute against a recalcitrant tout under section 291 of the Penal Code (Cap. 224). Any tout convicted under this section shall be punished with a fine or up to six months' imprisonment or both.

    Sir, other agencies are also involved in tackling this problem. The Singapore Tourist Promotion Board adopted the "carrot approach" jointly with the Consumers Association in the promotion of the Associate Membership Scheme in 1986. This is a long-term measure to discourage shops from engaging the services of touts.

    All these efforts cannot effectively curb the problem of touts because the existing provisions of the law against touting are inadequate. To deal with the touts more effectively, the Government has therefore decided to amend the Minor Offences Act to make touting in a public place a specific offence and to provide for severe punishment for offenders. These amendments have been finalized and the Bill will be introduced tomorrow.

    The Government, at the same time, has also decided to amend the Trade Marks Act to increase the penalties for the sale of counterfeit goods. These amendments, as well as other amendments to the Trade Marks Act, are now being drafted.

Column: 202

JUDICIAL AND LEGAL SERVICES
(Remuneration and Career development)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Davinder Singh -

    5. To ask the Minister for Finance whether it is intended to restore the starting pay in the Legal Service from $1,400 to $1,600; and, if not, what incentives are there for top legal graduates to join the Legal Service.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Toa Payoh GRC): Question No. 5, Sir.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, remuneration and career development in the Judicial and Legal Services is one of the issues being studied by a Committee on Scholarships and Civil Service Careers which was recently set up by the Government. The Committee is headed by BG Lee Hsien Loong (Minister for Trade and Industry and Second Minister for Defence (Services)). Other members include BG George Yeo (Minister of State for Finance and Foreign Affairs), Mr Mah Bow Tan (Minister of State for Trade and Industry and Communications and Information), Dr Cheong Siew Keong (Second Deputy Chairman of the Public Service Commission), and Dr Andrew Chew (Head of the Civil Service) and other senior public servants.

    The Committee has been given broad terms of reference to review and recommend improvements to the present system of public sector personnel management to ensure that the public service continues to attract and retain the best talent in Singapore. It will examine present organizational arrangements, scholarship terms, promotional policies and salary scales. Details of the Committee's terms of reference have been distributed to Members.

    The Committee should be ready to recommend whether to raise starting salaries in the Judicial and Legal Services by the Budget in March, although other recommendations will come later.

Column: 203



    I can assure the Member for Toa Payoh GRC that the Government will review salaries and service conditions of the Judicial and Legal Services to ensure that they are attractive to good legal minds in Singapore. Government is aware that officers of the Legal Service play an important role in the public affairs of Singapore. Judicial and Legal Officers man the courts and the Attorney-General's Chambers. Legal Officers are also heads of several government departments and are therefore also directly involved in policy formulation as well as the administration of these departments. It is therefore imperative that the Judicial and Legal Services attract an adequate share of able law graduates each year.

Column: 203

FOREIGN WORKERS' LEVY


    6. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Labour (a) what is the total amount of the levy on foreign workers collected in 1988 and estimated to be collected for 1989; and (b) for how many years will the rate of $250 per worker be maintained.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total amount of levy on foreign workers collected in 1988 was $218 million. The collection for 1989 is likely to be higher at about $400 million in view of the recent levy increases.

    The levy is a pricing mechanism. It is a flexible instrument. It can go down as well as up depending on the economic situation and the demand for foreign workers. There is therefore no fixed period for the levy to remain at a certain level.

Column: 203

PAID MATERNITY BENEFITS FOR THIRD CHILD


    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    7. To ask the Minister for Labour whether he will introduce legislation to amend Part IX of the Employment Act to provide for paid maternity benefits to female workers on the delivery of their third child.

     Dr Vasoo: Question No. 7, Sir.

Column: 204



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the possibility of amending the Employment Act to extend paid maternity benefits to the third child was considered during the formulation of the package of incentives to encourage procreation. Instead of paid maternity benefits, the Government decided that a tax incentive should be given to working mothers who have to take unpaid maternity leave for their third child. Such working mothers can claim additional tax rebate equivalent to 15% (or about two months) of their annual earned income.

    I will therefore not be introducing legislation to amend the Employment Act to provide for paid maternity benefits for the third child.

    The maternity benefit provisions in the Employment Act should be viewed in the context of the total package of incentives to support the new population policy.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [16th January, 1989],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mr Abdullah Tarmugi].

    The Minister of State for Communications and Information and Trade and Industry (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by the Member for Siglap, thanking the President for his Address to Parliament.

Column: 205



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the President began his Address to this Seventh Parliament with these words: "My Government's goal is to create a better life for all Singaporeans." Simple, short and sweet. In this one sentence, Sir, is captured the reason that brings us together in this House. In it also is captured the hopes and dreams of all Singaporeans.

    However, realizing this dream is far from simple. It is certainly not achievable in a short time and the measures to be taken may not always be sweet. But I remember a line from a poem written by an American, Carl Sandburg, which went something like this: "Nothing happens unless first a dream". We have such a dream. It is up to us to make it happen.

    In 1984, the Government unveiled a Vision - a vision to build, by 1999, a Nation of Excellence and a Society of Distinction.

    Then we had the National Agenda discussions, a process of consultation, of fine-tuning, of arriving at a consensus, of making sure that we are all dreaming the same dream. Finally, out of all this came the Agenda for Action.

    Sir, while on the question of consultation, yesterday the hon. Member for Fengshan criticized the Ministry of Communications and Information for not discussing the diesel and road tax increases with the GPC beforehand. Yes, the Government is committed to a consultative process of decision - making and of building consensus. The Member must know that the Government has done much to facilitate this process. But as an experienced Member, he must also know that there are certain issues which the Government cannot discuss beforehand. And one such issue is the timing of tax increases. The reason is very simple. It is to protect Members of Parliament from being accused of benefitting from such inside information.

    Sir, may I return to the dream? Over four years have passed. One term of government has been completed. We are almost one-third of the way towards 1999. How have we done so far? Are we on the right track? Are we on schedule?

Column: 206



    Our economy has shaken off the problems of the recession and emerged stronger, fitter and more broad based. Our national wealth has grown by 6% per annum, notwithstanding the years of zero and negative growth. The City is being transformed not only by the building of the new but also by the restoration of the old. The MRT has moved smoothly into our lives. Exciting plans for Marina City have been revealed. The people turned up in full force to celebrate National Day 1988 and an unprecedented 250,000 people turned Orchard Road into the world's biggest disco one hot August night last year.

    Sir, I believe we are on the right track and on schedule to our dream of a Nation of Excellence by 1999.

    And yet, Mr Speaker, Sir, all does not appear to be well. The results of the last General Election tell us something. We have all done our analysis of the voting patterns and we have all come to our own conclusions. But one message is coming through loud and clear, that Singaporeans want to see some Opposition in Parliament, even as they want to have a good government. I therefore strongly support the Government's intention to not only review the NCMP scheme but also to increase the number of NCMPs. I believe that not only is this sensitive to the wishes of the people, but that it will also educate the people on what makes for good government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is another voting pattern that is developing which suggests to me that all is not well. I am referring to those who voted not with their hands but with their feet. I am reminded of the remarks that the Member for Ayer Rajah once made in this House during the last Parliament, and I quote:

    'Running a country is not like running a company. We cannot sack our people if they are less effective.' The Member for Ayer Rajah is correct. We cannot "sack" our people if they are not good enough.

    But let us not forget that there is nothing to stop them from "resigning" and leaving the country if they feel that we are not good enough. Like any good management, I suggest the Government should take a closer look at what is going on. We

Column: 207

should do so not only because we are losing precious manpower and talent, a loss that we can ill afford. We should also do so because it tells us why it is happening and what we can do about it. Who are leaving? Why are they leaving? What are they looking for? What are their hopes and aspirations? It is possible that we may not like some of the answers that we get. But I am reassured because it has never been the nature of this Government to shy away from the truth no matter how unpleasant. To ignore this problem, Sir, is to ignore a time bomb ticking in our midst.

    Sir, every generation has its own aspirations, built on the foundations laid by the hard work of the last. Young Singaporeans have grown up in an era of political stability and high economic growth. They want to enjoy the fruits of what their country has achieved.

    If they perceive that the gains are not commensurate with the effort they have put in, or the sacrifices that they have made, I believe they will seek out new opportunities where these aspirations can be realised, in their life-time. The challenge that the government faces is how to create opportunities and options for Singaporeans to realise these personal aspirations, given the constraints that exist in Singapore.

    When our forefathers came to Singapore, it was in search of the good life. This they have achieved for themselves through their sacrifices, their hard work and their trust in good, strong government. But just as our forefathers came to Singapore for the better life, so too the younger generation are seeking first the economic rewards in the country that their fathers have built. There is, however, one major difference, then and now. Today, the young Singaporean, well-educated, highly-skilled, literate in English, has many options open to him - Canada, United States, Australia, New Zealand.

    In my conversations with Singaporeans, professionals in their early '30s, I sense this strong urge, this desire, to acquire the symbols of the good life - among other things, a house, a car; especially a car. Some professionals jokingly tell me that when their friends or relatives from abroad visit them, they often ask, "So you earn a

Column: 208

good salary... where's your car?" Sir, the challenge in our case is this. Given that we have limited road space, given that we need to keep these roads relatively congestion free, can we work out some viable options such that, within these constraints, Singaporeans can still be able to afford to own a car, the modern-day symbol of the good life.

    Two days ago in this House, Sir, we heard the Member for Bukit Timah talk about "child ownership" when he meant "car ownership". Maybe he did not make a mistake after all, for to some Singaporeans a car is almost as precious as a child!

    Then there are those who feel that Singapore is too cramped, too small. They long for the wide open spaces, the long drive in the countryside, the rolling hills and the plains. We may not have much to offer in this respect, although I must add that we should not short change ourselves. Four million tourists must know something that we do not. However, given the real desire to get away from it all, we can create the environment and the opportunity for Singaporeans to hold good paying jobs, still have enough time left over to spend their holidays in countries with wide open spaces and rolling hills and plains.

    Sir, as we have made the world our market place, there is no reason why we cannot make it our playground. Apart from this quality of life, there is also the quality of our work life. We spend the greater part of our waking hours at the work place. The Government cannot intervene directly at the work place. But it can provide the encouragement, the incentives, for companies to improve the quality of work life for their employees.

    Government can look after the basic housing, medical and educational needs of the population. Companies, however, should be encouraged to supplement and complement these with schemes of their own - housing/renovation loans, better medical benefit schemes, and retraining and skills upgrading programmes for their employees.

    Sir, there is yet another group of people who decide to leave because they feel they cannot cope with the pressures of our lifestyle. As the Member for Siglap

Column: 209

mentioned a few days ago, "they feel constrained and restless." They want less regulations, more freedom. I hear people complain that ours is a "one-mistake" society with no room for failure, no second chance. They do not want their children to be pressured in school. They do not want to be told to excel. In short, they want to opt out of the rat race. Unfortunately, Sir, some of these people discover too late that they have opted out from one rat race only to land in another, but with different rats.

    Sir, we aim to be a Nation of Excellence. There is nothing for us to be apologetic about. As the Minister for Communications and Information put it recently, excellence for all does not mean all of us being number one, but each one of us fulfilling our potential and being the best we can be. Nobody can quarrel with this. Perhaps it may have been misunderstood, in which case we should make it clearer.

    However, I sometimes wonder whether it is only a matter of more freedom, less pressure, or whether it is also a perception of being able to get greater or even the same returns for less effort. Is it possible? Can we get more for less? Experience has shown that this may be sustainable in the short term, but not in the long run, no matter how well-endowed the country.

    How else then can we, a country with much less natural resources, make it except to reward talent, effort, resourcefulness and hard work?

    Maybe there are those who feel that the pyramid is too narrow at the top, that opportunities are not available here for them to fulfil their full potential. If this is the case, then we should not discourage them from leaving or make them feel that they are traitors to the cause or close the doors to their return. Instead, let us encourage them to venture but leave their hearts behind, to make their mark on the world stage, but always to keep their links. And let us welcome them back - whether they are footballers, singers, scientists or managers - when they are ready to return.

    Sir, I highlight the emigration issue because I believe it is one of the key factors

Column: 210

that could affect our long-term growth. The brain drain may only be a trickle now, but let us make sure it does not turn into a flood. We cannot stop anyone from leaving, but if we can fulfil his potential and his personal aspirations - whether it is owning an apartment, or a car, or holidays abroad or more leisure activities - why should he leave? If we can give him hope that tomorrow can and will be better than today for him and for his family, why should he subject himself and his family to the uncertainty of the future in another country?

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, if we can make him feel that he has a role to play and a contribution to make to the development of his country, that he belongs here, that this is his home, I see no reason why we cannot meet the realistic aspirations of all Singaporeans during the next decade and achieve our vision of a Nation of Excellence.

    Sir, I support the motion.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I rise on a point to clarify on what the Minister of State said?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, the Minister of State imputed that I did not understand the process of what can and cannot be discussed with the Minister. Did I for one moment ask or mentioned anything about the timing of the tax? I talked about the consultative process, about discussing the issue. That is all, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Sir, the new GPC Chairman for Communications and Information is also a first-term MP. And he is also well aware of it. He mentioned to me that as a member of the Telecoms Board, he is aware that there may be conflicts of interest. We are well aware, Sir, and we know that you are a watchman and that you will watch over us. We are aware of this, Sir.

    Thank you for the reminder, Sir.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to respond to the Member for Fengshan.

    Sir, the Member for Fengshan gave a very spirited and vigorous speech yester-

Column: 211

day. I believe he left the impression with the House and definitely with the media that there has been little or no consultation. And as a result of that the Straits Times in its article today started off its article on the speech by the hon. Member, and I quote:

    'Dr Arthur Beng (Fengshan) yesterday chided the Government for reneging on a promise to adopt a more consultative approach when formulating important policies.'

    Sir, I want to ask the Member for Fengshan whether the Straits Times has got him right, whether that was his intention, or whether he might have been misunderstood, that he was saying that the Government has gone back on its promise to be more consultative, in particular with respect to the Ministry of Communications and Information.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the media is entitled to its opinion. I never used the word "chide", I never intended it to be a chide. I expressed what was my personal viewpoint and that was what I did.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, may I ask the Member whether he did intend to convey the message, the impression, that there had been no consultation with the Government Parliamentary Committee?

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, on the issue of diesel tax, I conveyed the message that there could have been much more consultation. We were not consulted on the diesel tax and that was the example that I brought up.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I concede that point. My Minister of State has given the explanation as to why it is not possible to discuss matters that are time sensitive or price sensitive or tax matters. It is Government's policy to ensure that none of our MPs can ever be falsely accused of taking advantage of information that they may have obtained in their capacity. In this way we protect our MPs. Our MPs do not know time sensitive tax matters.

    Sir, may I ask the Member before he rises again another question: whether he had been satisfied with the level of consultation on other matters other than the fact that he had not been told the timing and the quantum of road tax and diesel tax.

Column: 212



     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Minister for his concern for us MPs. But surely the Minister can consult with the MPs on matters of principle. I am not asking him the quantum of the tax or when tax is going to be implemented. Principles can, of course, be discussed.

    As far as the level of consultation, if you refer to my speech, Sir, I would say that I have mentioned that in the last five years that we have made good progress in consultation. It was these few examples that I brought up which to me are a cause of concern and I was expressing them.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I asked specifically concerning the Ministry of Communications and Information over the last two years when the Member was Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, I unequivocally say here that I have been very satisfied up to that point.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I think this is very important. When Government is accused of reneging on its promise to be consultative, it is not a laughing matter. It is a very serious matter.

    Sir, the Member in his speech yesterday used one single example, the reasons for which I personally have explained to the Member earlier on prior to the press release on this particular matter why we cannot as a Ministry, as a Government, discuss this matter with him earlier.
